newsitem.title: FRANCE: French stocks drop sharply at opening.
newsitem.headline: French stocks drop sharply at opening.

text.p: Losses flooded CAC-40 stocks at Thursday's opening, with the blue chip index starting down 0.99 percent. Traders said there was scope for profit-taking as today is the last day of this month's trading account.
Markets are also cautious over possible U.S. interest rate tightening on March 25 and sharp falls in bond markets.
The blue-chip CAC-40 index was down 29.86 points or 1.15 percent at 2,566.91 at 0918 GMT while the CAC-40 futures contract was down 28 at 2,572 from Wednesday's close.

There was little appetite to buy French stocks in anticipation of the new account in the uncertain climate in German and U.S. markets, said a broker. Investors are eyeing the 2,530-2,550 area on the CAC index as a buying zone.

Despite the sharp drop in share prices, there has been no big increase in trading volumes and the consolidation was fairly orderly. Profit-taking on dollar-exposure stocks or companies reporting disappointing results led the falls.
LVMH reverses earlier loss, up 0.99 percent to 1,323. The luxury goods and drinks company earlier reported a 1996 net attributable profit of 3.68 billion francs, lower than market estimates.
Alcatel Alsthom falls 2.33 percent to 670, as investors booked profits after strong gains prompted by 1996 results.
Elf Aquitaine, another CAC heavyweight, drops 2.33 percent to 546, amid profit-taking.
Lafarge, another stock which has risen on the back of recent dollar strengthening, now is also hit by profit-taking. The stock was down 3.82 percent at 375.1 francs.
Renault swerves into loss, down 3.26 percent at 133.5 francs, after recent rises. Market estimates for 1996 net losses, due to be announced later today, range between 4.5 billion-six billion francs.
